we talk about design thinking as a culture and it's about creating a culture that has certain new
Norms it is about a culture of creative confidence if you get an opportunity David Kelly just did a TED talk at the
last Ted conference on Creative confidence linking the work of a psychologist here at Stanford Albert
bandora um who has studied how people achieve self-authorship
self-efficacy um and has a model for that and it turns out what we do to teach people how to be more Innovative

a notion of re-engaging people's I me everyone is creative sort of naturally but they've lost the ability to be um uh

confidence um we use a lot of techniques in in the ideation block of our model to
um teach people to re uh re access their massively uh parallel unconscious um
thinking that happens all the time how to reconnect to um all forms of thinking
not just intellectual rational but emotional kinesthetic U visual thinking
um and uh through training in these techniques um teams become more faasil
at um having good ideas and following uh their intuition um we talked about design

soft word to uh introduce into the culture of business we don't often think
of business as being empathic um but um what we believe is that uh any smart
team given a problem will come up with a good answer but the team that connects
their their work to the actual Human Experience the human need behind
whatever problem they are trying to solve will be the one that has more and
better data they will come up with this interesting both emotional and uh and
usability information that comes from the direct observation of their users
this has also some seems to be one of the more radical Notions in our in our um idea about design thinking often when

typically they're talking about customers being the people they sell to for instance in uh in the tool industry
we sell to Home Depot and Lowe's so we talk to the Home Depot and Lowe's buyers we know our customer very well but when
we actually say if you ever talk to somebody who's trying to hang a picture and they've got a hammer and a nail and

that and understand the difficulty they have positioning the picture correctly leveling the picture getting it to hang
the way they want it the frustration they have with finding a stud that and all the other things and they go well
why would we do that you know we don't sell to them we sell to loaves and um we find that
breaking down that barrier going that that that last mile to the actual customer and using the tools that we
take from anthropology and ethnography to do observation of customer needs and
this can be you know service product like designing a new service for a bank or a financial institution can be in a
product product I was seven years at Apple computer before I came to Stanford and we uh despite the rumor that that
Apple does no market research which is kind of of true they do tons and tons of empathy research to make products as
simple and easy and intuitive to use as as Apple products typically are you need
to really understand where people get stuck and how they misunderstand the use of products so we
do a lot of work in the empathy area and we do that upfront to sort of load up a
team a smart team with information that most other teams don't have and this is partly how we unlock
the problem as Mark said because I'm thinking is more about F problem finding than it is problem
solving you know again most smart teams are great at problem solving the trick is getting them to work on the correct
problem and often we find that it takes a deep dive with the real um users
involved in uh the problem you're trying to solve and a lot of direct observation
of the users in their environment to to understand what is frustrating them you see users can't tell what they need they
can't say well if you would redesign your product like this it would be perfect but they can show you what they're frustrated with and they can
show you the difference between what they say and do they may say you know it's this is fine I don't have any
problems and then when you watch them you discover all the little workarounds they're doing in order to get their job
done so that's the data that we think really tends to unlock the problem and
allow us to step back and reframe the problem as not what everybody else is working on but something new
so if you create this culture of creativity and a culture of empathy the
next thing you do is you you teach people how to have a culture of ideas um
where ideas are are you you're never you're never working off of one idea or two ideas or three ideas but that you
start every process generating literally hundreds of ideas I'm in the middle of teaching the class right now um thing
called the summer arts intens um and uh it is not uncommon for a
design team in that class when given a design challenge they have a maybe a 24-hour challenge to sit down uh

through a selection process of what they really want to work on to build and we find that um although most people say
they brainstorm and most people say yeah you know we we we have plenty of ideas around here when you really dig down and
you sort of metric what's going on people are working one inside a very limited range of ideas around a central
theme and two that they don't have literally hundreds and hundreds of ideas
so if you generate a lot of ideas and you link those ideas to your observations your empathy observations
of user needs you tend to redefine problems in way that really create kind
of new value the other thing is prototyping and this is an you know this is an interesting example of somebody gluing
some weird little thing together and it looks kind of crappy and uh it's kind of rough and uh that's exactly the sort of
stuff we encourage you see the thing here is that you're working on what is called a classically wicked problem if
you're really trying to redefine your industry or just redefine how you submit expense reports you know up up through
the food chain and get them signed off no matter what the level of problem is if the problem has people involved in it
then the problem is a classically wicked problem and we problems don't have good solutions they just have better and
worse they don't have you know right solutions they just have stuff that will work for now and typically once you've
proposed the solution to a problem and it's okay new problems emerge and and
you know this probably describes almost everything we work on nowadays um when we're redesigning services or we're
taking on you know the the challenge of working in uh devel developing countries and providing um solutions for water
agriculture poverty and other things the problems are big and they're very messy and no matter how well defined you think
your your problem statement is and no matter how well you've brainstormed and come up with many many ideas it turns
out as soon as you start building something new problems emerge and so we
we really really believe in the concept of failing early and failing often failing at a very low resolution so that
people can try things and um and discover the facts as they go forward
um people often say well why is design thinking different than anything else it's just a problem solving tool but I
think this prototyping thing is one of the things that makes it quite different you know I'm trained as an engineer and
I use a lot of engineering thinking when I have a a tightly bound problem and I have enough equations I can solve the
problem and find the unknown um in in engineering thinking you solve your way forward you you find the one right

um if if you know uh Business Schools teach another form of thinking I'd call business thinking where you're making

sometimes be but you still have a figure of Merit this company makes more money than that company it's more profitable
their uh return on assets is better um in a versus B the Strategic fit you five
for Porters five forces or a SWAT analysis tells me the Strategic fit of a is better than b
um uh so there there are ways of making decisions and creating some figure of
Merit around the decisionmaking so in engineering we solve our way forward and in business we decide our way forward
but when you run across problems where there is no way to get enough data to make a an accurate decision and you
certainly can't solve for anything because people are involved so it's too messy we believe you build your way
forward you literally build solutions to inquire into into the problem to get to
the next layer of the problem so these prototypes that we talking about these rough prototypes are designed to fail
they are very low resolution they typically leave out a lot of data but they're designed to pose a question and
they're another way of inquiring with the user um in the same way that we use empathy to sort of see um what is going
on in the situation and how might a a really simple prototype elicit the next
of discussion so we really view prototypes as a way of asking questions creating a social dialogue with users
the other thing by the way that prototypes do which is sort of unintended but but quite wonderful is prototypes get the design team or the
team working on the problem uh all grounded together often how many times have you been on a team where everybody
thought we all knew exactly what we were talking about and then when we made the slides and went to do the presentation we all went that's not what we're
talking about is it um prototypes help us um pull the team together and then
ask questions you know out in the world where the real problem exists um I want to I want to just you I
close with this quote so you know design thinking culture is a culture of creative confidence that uses prototypes
to inquire about the world it's a culture of ideas and it generates ideas in a very flexible and fluid Manner and
um it is fundamentally you know about setting up the conditions that allow people to fail
early fail often so that they can succeed sooner and that deals with a class of problems that neither business
thinking or engineering thinking is equipped to solve um now we all have a process and

um was walking through a u uh one of the Ford engineering buildings and one of the young Engineers who was frustrated

back uh probably you know in uh the early uh 2000s um Ford was failing to make cars

why they weren't making cars that anybody liked um and anyway Alan's walking through the lunchroom and

seem to care more about stage Gates and rules and and coming up with numbers and
metrics than we care about making cars that people really really love and um uh
Mele to his credit so so stepped back and thought about it and he realized he was managing the wrong things he was man
you know what managers do is they have systems of information and control Finance is a way of managing financial
information and controlling uh the rate of spending and what he's invested in um
you can manage process which is important and certainly everybody has stage gates for Innovation but he
realized that the the the managing process was not emphasizing the kind of culture he wanted to create that car
that in fact forward wasn't a car culture that they' lost their passion for building great cars and he realized
that culture is probably the most important thing that a manager manages and again culture's had
invisible set of rules about what does it mean to come to work today and what are you going to do what the engineer
young engineer was telling him is that when I come to work what I expect to do is fill out a lot of paperwork and
answer a lot of questions about where I am in my process but I don't come in um
and read all the car magazines and go out to the studio and talk to the designers and go out to the you know RAC
trcks and talk to the people who really really love you know what the Ford
Mustang represents in terms of an iconic um piece of technology in our culture
and uh Mally changed his mind he changed the way he was um managing things Ford
has been rather successful ium the only company that didn't take a bailout and um he he credits it to the fact that he
started managing a different kind of control system he managed culture rather than process sorry always I always love
that quote because it it it's you know you can we have a design thinking process it starts with empathy then we
redefine the problem then we go to you know ideation and prototyping and testing But ultimately if you understand
that what you're changing first is yourself the culture of your yourself what you plan to do when you come to
work today are you going to just write a lot of emails and do a lot of things are you going to make some time for
Innovation and ideas and once you've decided to manage yourself differently you can always manage your group
differently The Five People You work with and instead of worrying about where you are in the process you want to be
mindful of that but you also want to be you know thinking about how are we creating a culture of ideas today how
are we uping people's creative confidence today and what are we doing to engage our users with some tangible
objects prototypes of services experiences whatever um to get some data
um and you know how are we asking the important questions if you come into work with that attitude you'd be
surprised at how much you can change so it's really um you know like are
you doing things right but most people you know worry about if you're process driven you're worried about are you
doing things right are you Crossing all the teas and do all the eyes but design thinking asks a different question um
are you doing the right thing are you actually solving the right problem in 30 years of Consulting and I'm sure mark
would agree with me on this um typically the people who um bring you know
Consulting problems to um to my firm or to Stanford um have brought the wrong problem and most typically what they
brought is a symptom not the underlying solution so if you take the time to stop
and ask the question am I doing the right thing rather than doing things right you are
often uh at the that top of the mountain when you're ready to let go of that Boulder that you really should be
thinking about am I looking at root causes am I looking at data from real
individuals and real users or am I just moving through a
process are you managing the present and we're all I think stuck in this problem
of you know the tyranny of the immediate but um you you should be thinking
certainly as a manager or as a group leader of how are you creating the future um the one of the reasons that
the rate of change is so overwhelming is that we're we're kind constantly caught up in sort of trying to manage this
present that uh where the rules keep changing and we're not quite sure where we are versus taking some time to put
into the culture this notion of creation um uh Roger Martin uh who is
the dean at the rotman school of management at Toronto in Toronto the business school there um who's a design
thinking Advocate wrote a book called the design of business you could look at that if you're interested in a business text um Roger says it shouldn't be an
MBA which is the management of business administration because he doesn't think he's teaching people to administer things he wants to make it an MBC a
management of business creation because that's actually what what what you should be working on how are we creating
a future that's sustainable and that grows that's blue ocean that's you know that's new and different if you have an
opportunity to ask those questions at least some percentage of your time shifting it from the managing the
present to creating the future um you're starting to build a culture of design
thinking and fundamentally it's about changing um you know decid of changing paradigms we were working with a
probably the world's leading the largest supplier um of industrial parts for both
um the Auto industry the white goods industry you know um this is just a this is a major multinational organization um
and they are expert leaders in providing components to um a number of key
Industries um but they're sort of stuck on you know the growth rate is stagnant

kind of description of what they needed to do they needed to move from supplying
a component you know a shock absorber to a vehicle to thinking about how the
shock absorber is part of a system of traction control it's a part of a system
of autonomous driving it's coming coming very quickly you know to Vehicles near you and from moving from a components to
a systems um orientation would require them to work differently different parts of their organization who provide
individual components would have to radically collaborate to provide new system solutions to the automakers but
that that was one thing that they agreed would probably generate huge amounts of
um new opportunity they make a lot of sensors you know Vehicles washing machines everything has sensors in it
temperature sensors water sensors pressure sensors but if you think of sensors as just an object that goes in a

America um and if you think of yourself as a plumbing manufacturer you think of yourself you know turning brass and

other ways to provide you know services where we used to consider cars a standalone vehicle um now they'll be
connected in networks through the cloud and that the potential for that in terms
of car safety um car autonomy um and um in infotainment systems and everything
else um is just enormous so this is an example of how moving from one Paradigm
to the other could radically change uh this organization's business and they are in process of putting in place all
four of these initiatives uh worldwide across our organization Alan Kay who's a computer

anybody the best way to predict the future is to invent it that's what we did at Apple when I was there for seven
